comments.body: This looks like it's only used in one spot (https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/84522/files#diff-76b7e314f9618c8bc2ca6442ddd35dc3R448), does that need to be a constant?

I don't think whether a var is used once or multiple times determines whether it should be a constant or not. Having it here is just more consistent and easy to read with other constant strings. Let me know if you think otherwise.

comments.body: Can we make the logic UTed?
Added UT
Putting it into a closure so that we can always get the correct `status` instead of zero value. üëç
It seems like we back to use the "separate data and logic" approach.

> It seems like we back to use the "separate data and logic" approach.

yes, but there is a difference between the reason we are doing it here and what you suggested in your PR: you separated the data but made it local to the function, you didn't identify or argued that there is an opportunity to reuse the "data" in other places, and so I still stand by my opinion that that wasn't useful and it only bloated the function.

The situation here is different: 1) we added another function (listPlugins) that needed to iterate over the same set of extension points, 2) identified a third existing function (pluginsNeeded) that also needed to iterate the same extension points.

Is the difference clear?
SorryÔºåsir Ôºåthis name ‚ÄúPodToleratesNodeTaint‚Äù seems little Confuse to me„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ
Since this has same signature as that of updater.AddPod , it seems this func (RunPreFilterUpdaterRemovePod) can be unified with RunPreFilterUpdaterAddPod by passing AddPod / RemovePod as parameter.
why not keep the functions and just make them local (normalizeScores and applyScoreWeights)?

I just found the 3 steps are very similar (parallel execution and receive error) and it looks good to me to put them in the same function (saves a few lines of code). But no particular reason really.

If you like the separately, I can change it.

I think we should also send an error over the `errCh`. We currently ignore a faulty plugin and only log a message. These log messages may remain unnoticed for a while. I would prefer a more serious action, like not scheduling the pod so that a cluster admin notices the issue.
If you decided to go with my suggestion, you may want to remove the `klog.Errorf` above and only send an error message over `errCh`.
SG

comments.body:
Thanks for the catch. I believe there are other occurrences in this or related files. Can you please change them all?

/assign @ahg-g 
for a thorough check.

sg, please do the same throughout the file as @Huang-Wei suggested.

There are a couple of cases in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/scheduler/algorithm/priorities/interpod_affinity.go as well
We could precheck it when initializing the NormalizeSocrePlugins.
If this is a requirement for running normalizes extension point, we could embed ScorePlugin into NormalizeScorePlugin.

@bsalamat  has clarified this in [this comment](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/80383#discussion_r306044447). I am going to add precheck logic to make sure that the list of enabled Normalize Score extension points is a subset of Score extension points. And hence the check here is not needed.

Here, you are assuming that `NormalizeScore` plugins have the exact same names as the `score` plugins. This is a valid assumption, but as I mentioned in my other comment, you should ensure that this assumption is valid.
I am going to add logic during framework initialization to make sure NormalizeScore extension points are a subset of Score extension points.

1. Added verification logic in framework initialization to make sure an enabled NormalizeScore plugin is also enabled as a Score plugin.
2. Embed Score interface in NormalizeScore interface to make sure a NormalizeScore plugin is always a Score plugin.

Do you think there is anything else missing here?
Resolving since we now only rely on the ScorePlugin plugin set. NormalizeScorePlugin plugin set is going to be removed in next PR.

An alternative is to run NormalizeScore plugins in the same `RunScorePlugins`. That would helps save on memory by not passing a large map around, but it would reduce parallelism. I haven't gone through all the issues that it could introduce, so I leave it up to you.

```
```

I have discussed this with @ahg-g. As you said, there is a trade-off between saving memory vs. reducing parallelism. I have chosen to optimize for parallelism. Since I am new to scheduler, I don't have enough data points to prove that the tradeoff I made is optimal.

I will keep it as is unless you have further comments.

Weight is currently applied in ```RunScorePlugins```. We need to change that and apply the weight after NormalizeScore, if a NormalizeScore plugin exist.

If we are going with this current code structure, we need to add a ApplyScoreWeights function that gets called after RunNormalizeScorePlugins in generic_scheduler.go.

> That would helps save on memory by not passing a large map around

This is not a problem since passing a map to another method only copies the pointer to the map which is only 8 bytes.

> > That would helps save on memory by not passing a large map around
> 
> This is not a problem since passing a map to another method only copies the pointer to the map which is only 8 bytes.

I think the suggestion was to tradeoff parallelism for space. Basically run the plugins sequentially, parallelising across nodes only. If we do this, then we just need to maintain two N-sized arrays instead of kN arrays (where k is the number of plugins)

Yesterday, when I was thinking about this I did the math. Since we store one integer per node per plugin, in a cluster with 10K nodes and 20 priority functions, we will store less than 1MB of data (10,000 * 20 * 4). This is not a problem. We need to ensure that we do not allocate and release memory frequently though. Allocation and GC time could degrade performance significantly if we are not careful. We should preallocate all slices (which we do). If we could reuse these slices for other pods that would be even better, but it'd introduce some complexities when nodes are added to the cluster. For now, we can stick to the current implementation and change it in the future if there is a need.

+1 on applying weights "after" normalize score.
Same as [comment](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/80383/files#r307218003), we could skip the check. Then there is no error in this func, and we do not need `errCh` to deal with errors.
ditto comment above.

comments.body: We need to do an exist check because in reality Name() could return something different from the name set in the config.
If it does not exist, the value of `weight` will be 0, so it is same to check whether it is 0.
ok, sounds good then.

I wonder if the check on line 98 should handle 0 value similarly (returning error):
```
		if f.pluginNameToWeightMap[name] == 0 {
```
The [comment](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/80305#discussion_r304919930) explained it.
nit: extra new line
comments neededÔºÅ

we should distinguish between success/unschedulable and all other statuses. if success or unschedulable, then we return directly, otherwise we should probably convert the status to Error like we do for other extension points.

Filter plugins are special, as their returned message is shown to the user. For example, if there is not enough memory on a node, we put a message in pod status which is similar to "10 nodes insufficient memory". The part that formats the message for end user is in the scheduler code in `predicates.NewFailureReason()`, but the "reason" part of the message (which is "insufficient memory" in the above example) is important. We should not alter the `status.Message` here for that reason. So, returning `status` as is, is fine IMO. We may want to check for error and log errors though.
Message is logged once the plugin returns failure.
+1 to @ahg-g's suggestion. It makes sense to convert all codes other than "Unschedulable" to an `Error`
@YoubingLi this hasn't been addressed yet. I left a comment with the suggestion.

The suggestion in the previous comment is to do something like this:

```
errMsg := fmt.Sprintf("RunFilterPlugins: error while running %s filter plugin for pod %s: %s",
					p.Name(), pod.Name, status.Message())
klog.Errorf(errMsg)
return NewStatus(Error, errMsg)
```
It has been addressed in the latest diff
Could these plugins run concurrently? Ref: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/80039
They could, I think. lets leave that for a separate PR.
OK. I'll handle them all in the PR for #80039.
Please handle "status == nil" case.
it is already handled by the IsSuccess function: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/scheduler/framework/v1alpha1/interface.go#L70

Need to pass parameters.
Sorry, thought it was a bracket
Why re-declare a new variable here instead of using maxTimeout directly?
timeout is used to track the minimum duration returned by any plugin. I added a comment to the interface documentation to clarify the semantics.
It would be good to clarify that if any plugin returns "wait", this function will continue running the remaining plugins.
Done.

An alternative to this approach is to support multiple plugins for QueueSort. We could rename `Less` function to `Cmp` and let it return -1, 0, or 1. A returned 0 means that the values are equal. In that case, we can call the next plugin Cmp until one returns non-zero. For now, I think we can stay with the current implementation.
For the current implementation, when len(f.queueSortPlugins) reaches 1, we don't need to append more plugin.

Updated. PTAL.
Thanks
I think all plugins in the registry are initialised here. Should we skip the plugins that are not specified in `Plugins`?
The `if _, ok := pg[name]; !ok` skips plugins that are not needed.

GitHub still does not make it easy to review changes relative to code review comments. /=
Please remove this blank line.

Squashed and pushed.
Thanks!!
specifying initial capacity is optional.
Should we check that the plugin has corresponding config ?
For now, I think it's okay to pass nil config into plugin factories. I'm not sure it would help to pass in an "empty" `runtime.Unknown` object.
